subject: Re: File Diff in JUnit
msgSnippet: Vitezslav, Thank-you for the JUnit file-diff extension.  The capability is exactly what I need. I am having a bit of a problem implementing it. If you could
messageBody:
Vitezslav,

Thank-you for the JUnit file-diff extension. The capability is
exactly what I need.

I am having a bit of a problem implementing it. If you could give me
an short example, I would appreciate it. Here is an outline of what I
have tried so far.

In the original post you requested an assert that would take two file
names and return a boolean. So, before reading .java files, I tried
the following and was told that there were not enough arguments:
assertFile("file1", "file2");

Then being stubborn I tried:
assertFile("file1", "file2", null);

This ran fine, however, file1 and file2 did not exist.

If you could provide an example of the diff parameter that needs to
be passed, I would appreciate it. The html mentioned a
junit.diff.SimpleDiff. I would like to use this. However, I cannot
find it in the package.

Once again, I would like to say that this is an excellent idea. It
would be nice to see the documentation expanded.

Faith

--- In junit@y..., Vitezslav Stejskal <vitezslav.stejskal@c...> wrote:
> Dear All,
>
> couple of days ago I asked for available file-diff capabilities in
JUnit.
> Jim answered me and posted code snippet, which I found useful, but
> not sufficiently for my task. Thus I developed simple extension of
> JUnit framework which allows to use file-diff in more convenient
way.
>
> Hopefully it could be useful for others as well, I would like to
continue
> in this work and will be pleasured to see it integrated in next
versions of
> JUnit framework. Please, let me know if this is possible.
>
> Sorry for the attachement, but it's very small, it contains the
description
> of announced extension as well as source codes and compiled classes.
>
> Thanks,
> Vita
>
>
>
>
> Jim Jackl-Mochel wrote:
>
> > I will simply repost the code that was sent to me originally when
I posted
> > the same question:
> >
> > > I don't have one coded up in a base class, but here is the code
I use...
> > >
> > > public void assertFilesEqual(File fileOne, File
fileTwo) {
> > > assertEquals(readFile(fileOne), readFile
(fileTwo));
> > > }
> > >
> > > private static String readFile(File fileToRead) {
> > > StringBuffer fileContents = new StringBuffer
("");
> > > try {
> > > BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader
(new
> > FileReader(fileToRead));
> > > String line;
> > > while ((line = in.readLine()) != null) {
> > > fileContents.append(line+"\n");
> > > }
> > > in.close();
> > > } catch (Exception e) {
> > > System.err.println(e.toString());
> > > return "";
> > > }
> > > return new String (fileContents);
> > > }
> > >
> >
> > Good luck.
> >
> > Jim JM
> >
